/COMMIT_MSG.message: If ansible needs sudo access, it will get it on localhost, because all of the users are in the sudo group via becomes: true. With that in mind, why don't we just change this group permissions to sudo (created by default), and just remove the ansible group?

Maybe but reading https://wiki.debian.org/sudo and group memberships, it seems like even though we are running ansible, we are in-fact going to be still using sudo for some tasks.  Rather then creating ansible group, then adding users to it, and duplicating the functionality of sudo and ansible groups, I'd rather see us just use sudo.

Reading your commit message on I6a7fdd460fb472f0d3468eb080aebbb010931e11 it says admin replaced by sudo, but we replaced existing admin folders with root, not sudoers.

I think I'd be more okay with creating an ansible group if we decided to add non sudo users into it, but I don't really see that happening either, due to nature of ansible and usage of becomes.

I don't think the two overlap?  If a playbook has becomes: true that just means the playbook is running at elevated privileges, but it doesn't mean ansible needs to be started as root.

I guess you're saying "everyone in the sudo group should be able to run ansible" which, while true, I think it's better to have one-group-one-thing if we can, just for sane separation.  I might suggest using the "admin" group was a bit of a confusing semantic (especially because ubuntu went and removed it during releases we transitioned through) and if it was a separate ansible group from the start, it would have been intrinsic documentation about what it's doing.

specs/dib-image-cache.rst.message:
It seems like were going to be duplicating a lot of effort and information that is already encoded in DIB elements. I wonder if we could use source-repositories in DIB to download the images well need for a set of elements, rsync those images to a mirror, then use the same source-repositories info to set the DIB overrides for image download locations...

The alternative is were going to have a bunch of specific per-image variables to set to override the locatoin, and we'll duplicate the caching logic which is already in DIB.

I agree with greghaynes on that, in the short term that we were using dib image generation, that kind of failures were happening very often. I added a spec related to that to ensure image tests, and this was one of the reasons.
So i'd love to see some integrated mechanism in nodepool to solve that.

I think this is a good idea, and will add it to next revision.  however, I also think it could be tackled somewhat asynchronously.  you're right it's a bit of manual fiddling with a yaml file and overrides in the dib job-script, but it's pretty straight forward and i think a pretty good first step

A periodic job sounds like it would run in Zuul, but then we would have to distribute credentials to specific slaves to do this.  Currenty, the pypi mirror is just a cron job on the mirror hosts themselves.  I think that would work here too.

(In Zuulv3 this should totally be a Zuul job.)

Note that we have a long-term plan to use AFS to back our mirrors so that we only have to run mirroring jobs in one place and AFS will distribute the data out to our mirrors (which will cache it locally).  This may be a good choice for that.  If it doesn't work, it will work just fine with our current "run in crontab on each host" system.

I agree - I'm getting more and more concerned with our current "put it all in the image" or "run our own mirror" or "both" approach - when in some cases caching proxies + somethign-that-will-actually-retry-a-fetch-for-one-in-its-life would be fine. I'm hoping that AFS gets us a bunch - but it's certainly worth look at caching proxies.

I think we will want a static mirror for some things (we can gain atomicity with full distro mirrors, for instance).  But I'm also thinking that it might be nice to have caching proxies as well, as the set of things we want to "mirror" becomes larger and more diverse, there may end up being low-hanging fruit where it's not worth our develping a full mirror infrastructure.

I'm not sure where this falls on the spectrum, so it would be good to evaluate it here.

I am not sure how manageable it is to maintain a cache proxy for distribution images.

A potential problem would be clients using HTTPS, maybe you can still cache them by having a trusted certificate authority on the proxy which would terminate the SSL connection and that the clients trust.


Some other random possibilities:

* rely on the cloud providers. Maybe they already have their own mirrors and could be part of the larger CDN?  This way when requesting something like clouds.centos.org  you end up hitting the cloud provider local mirror.  Highly speculative and would require the provider to do the mirroring work + attach it to the global CDN.

* mirror them on a local share filesystem that is mounted readonly. But then I am not sure you can `curl file:///mnt/ro-mirror/` and you would still have to handle the mirror update across several providers :-(
++ mirror.$region.o.o. (with a tiny thought that for providers in which we have multiple networks, perhaps it should be mirror.$region.$network.o.o ... but now I'm getting ahead of myself.

I'm not a fan of this name, but we can always discuss that later.

My suggestion would be ci-mirror or just mirror.

In fact, there is already some work in progress to do just that ("mirror.dfw.o.o", etc).  See these changes:

I8216eed658cc7b471c52ac1d1b6aeb62c296dfbd
Ied52454aceaf4b9d09f0f1ad422f9d8ae23da6a4

I am loosely evaluating https://github.com/epeli/angry-caching-proxy   A node.js server that supports gems/pip/npm/apt-get.  It has a few drawbacks though:

* needs to use an http mirror (no https)
* the cache holds all images in the same dir, might run out of indoors
* node.js (i.e. it is not python)
* last commit is two years old

I imagine a proxy system for package managers would be of good use for a lot of OpenStack installations.

playbooks/roles/configure_swap/tasks/mai.message:
Nit, when using blocks, we typically put extra bits like conditionals right below the blocks like so:


    - block:
      when: ephemeral_device is undefined
        - name: Find ...

This is more readable, especially when the block is large.

Oops, the syntax is reversed with blocks. You need to put the "when" before:

    - when: something is defined
      block:
        - task..

I learned this from the openshift-ansible folks, they use it a lot, example: https://github.com/openshift/openshift-ansible/blob/20cf3396e4aae5aef6485a23e6cc3134c7a2d1be/roles/openshift_repos/tasks/main.yaml#L7
Actually it seems the syntax is to have this after the tasks inside, as it then applies the when to each task

ahh, i totally mis-read this; it's easier when you put a name in there

- name: task name
  when: foo
  block:
    - list
    - of
    - tasks

Include tasks that have conditionals attached to them need to carry the "static: no" attribute.

http://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/playbooks_roles.html#dynamic-versus-static-includes

It feels like we shouldn't bother to run *any* of those tasks at all if we have enough swap -- that's why in my draft [1] I had put it at the playbook level.

(Note, my draft doesn't have a static:no, and it's an include task with a conditional so it probably needs one)

[1]: https://gist.github.com/dmsimard/d3d818462292faf92dded7e2caf67bab

So my thinking behind this was that we want to have idempotence as "low" as possible in the hierarchy; this also kind of plays into your comment on the sysctl

I like that the top level file is unconditional and just always runs.  Keeping things totally unconditional seems best as a strategy, however these two playbooks aren't quite idempotent -- I think the partitioning will redo itself on every run which is not what we want.  Longer term we could make these more idempotent and remove this check all together ... but I think this keeps us closer to the original code logic so let's not bite off more than we can chew at once :)

How about we take this out to a different role where we could end up setting different/various sysctl parameters ?
Otherwise, if we want to make sure this runs (ex: if we go with my idea at the playbook level) we'd need to put it outside the conditional. Maybe before the include_role task ?

As mentioned above, this seems to fit in here ... in the (very theoretical) case of a 3rd party doing this on their own host,  with 8gb of swap already setup we would still want to do this for consistency.

Since it's so easy to drop a sysctl: call in anywhere, I think it's best to leave things close by and rely on the idempotence again.

I think this command task can be dropped entirely. Then below you could just have:

    - name: Get ephemeral0 device node
      command: /sbin/blkid -L ephemeral0
      register: ephemeral0
      changed_when: False

    - name: Set ephemeral device if LABEL exists
      when: "ephemeral0.rc == 0"
      set_fact:
        ephemeral_device: "{{ ephemeral0.stdout }}"

Since blkid -L will return non zero when label does not exist.

doc/source/plugins.rst.message:
This is quite confusing. It can benefit from a metadata service capable of providing an username, but it doesn't *require* it.

I'd drop this sentence, and probably this whole notes section since it's a bit redundant, we're already saying the same thing at the 83-84 lines.

From what I can tell, you're using the notes section to specify which plugins make use of metadata services, which may require restarts and so on. One idea would be to have a matrix with the following columns: "Plugin name", "Requires reboot" (no, phase dependent, always), "Uses metadata service" (no, optional, mandatory), "Runs at every reboot".

This is specifically made like this to be searchable easy in the document and per plugin. When someone looks here, she usually looks for a specific plugin to understand how it works. If every plugin has a way to declare that it can reboot the system or needs metadata service to work, it s better to do it here. If we have a matrix, most of the fields in that matrix will be empty or default to no metadata, does not reboot, etc.

What can be confusing is the expression: May require capable metadata service. I am trying to look for another better expression.

Minor nit: s/is set to True/enabled/.

Besides, the config option is already saying exactly that. Actually, the "basic auth" option would also affect the http listener, so probably there's no need to explicitly mention https here.

On the other hand, it may be worth mentioning what "basic auth" actually does.
that replacement won t be nice, as it s doubling the enable word in the same phrase.

This is a bit confusing. LocalScriptsPlugin is executing scripts that already exist at a specified location, as opposed to UserDataPlugin, which is running scripts retrieved from the metadata service. We could mention this instead.
Using "execute" instead of "handle" sounds good. I still think we should also underline the distinction between them.

it can be changed to 'execute' instead of 'handle'. The thing is that these plugins execute the content of those scripts in the same way. it makes no difference if the script comes from the userdata or is a local script, if you have the same content, the result will be the same.

I suppose I can remove this part if it s confusing.

Minor nit: this sounds a bit odd. How about rephrasing as:

It posts the RDP certificate thumbprint to the metadata service endpoint .
I would just say: "The PRE-NETWORK stage". You already explain what it is in parenthesis.
I think you can provide these as a bullet point list. It saves the reader from having to scroll horizontally.

Probably the idea was to enumerate all available plugins while also providing a configuration sample.

What we might do is have just a couple of plugins in the config sample and add a separate bullet point list that includes all of them.

IMO, ideally there should be an automatically generated list of plugins (based on the code), probably as a matrix providing additional details about the plugins (e.g. based on certain class fields). Anyway, that can be done later.
The reason I put this here is for people to be able to copy paste the plugin list for customization of the configuration file.
"May require capable metadata service", just repeats the first bullet point. Either remove the first bulletpoint, or drop the first part of this one.

may run

Use "may" when you want to indicate the *possibility* of something. Use "can" to indicate its *ability* to do something. Use "will" (or something equivalent in the context) to indicate a certainty.

ie: It is possible that this plugin *may* run at every boot, given certain conditions.

Every plugin *can* technically run at every boot.
A particular plugin *will* run at every boot. Or The metadata service *will* provide a certain piece of information. 

Also, the first sentence is repetitive with the second one.
Requires support in the metadata service

It seems weird that we'd revert and end up with more than we had before the x-cell resize. Wouldn't it have been much easier to just block attaching block devices while an instance in the confirmation state or auto-confirm them or something? Correct, it would be an API change because the API allows attaching/detaching volumes while a server is resized:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/aa096fd18352fb9da94069ec2cab478eed5c6cca/nova/compute/api.py#L4435

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/aa096fd18352fb9da94069ec2cab478eed5c6cca/nova/compute/api.py#L4542

Thankfully we don't have that with things like attaching/detaching network interfaces:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/aa096fd18352fb9da94069ec2cab478eed5c6cca/nova/compute/api.py#L4674

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/aa096fd18352fb9da94069ec2cab478eed5c6cca/nova/compute/api.py#L4698

Or updating tags:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/aa096fd18352fb9da94069ec2cab478eed5c6cca/nova/api/openstack/compute/server_tags.py#L53

Mentioned in the spec as well:

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/ussuri/approved/cross-cell-resize.html#revert-flow

Since at least Dan and I discussed in the spec at some point the merits of being able to attach/detach volumes on a resized server. He had a use case for it but now I forget what it was.

lib/tempest.message:
Can we run this with "python3" instead of "python"? That would also work with Centos8 then, which no longer has python2 and thus no "python" binary.

See also https://review.opendev.org/697382

python command is easier to find than python3. I am pretty sure you can write an implementation of this command working with any python version working on any existing unix. For example:

 python -c 'import sys; print(int(sys.argv[1]) >> 30)' "${size}"

int(sys.argv[1]) translate the first arguments to integer. Integers in python are at least 64bit so are pretty fine for storing gigabytes values.

value >> 30 is a binary shift of 30 bits, that means dividing an integer by 1GB. Size units (by 1024 instead of by 1000) have actually been created to be processed by cpus CPUs build with few thousands of transistors. ;-)
If Jens thinks python3 is fine it's good with me, we originally saw python${PYTHON3_VERSION} in inc/python but it is in the code installing python itself.

In other locations where devstack-installed code is to be executed, it matters whether we installed stuff under e.g. py36 or py37 and we need to be specific about using the matching python executable, but in this case here, any python3 should work fine, so KISS rules. ;)
Good point. I'm mostly following Jens' recommendation to just use "python3" per: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/697382/2/lib/tempest

Thanks for the suggestions Federico.

The current implementation already works with both python versions (just drop the "3" from the python command, it was my original proposal).

That said, I find the bit shift a bit too black magic-ish for such a simple task (tho I like the GiB vs GB thing).

I will leave for other reviewers to decide. I just want to get this fixed cause it can currently break some local devstack deployments.

If you prefer division over shift (readability is a subjective question, it depends on what you are used to) you can then use below expression instead:

 python -c 'import sys; print(int(sys.argv[1]) / (1024 * 1024 * 1024))' "${size}"

The original implementation you are changing here it haves any right math basis and I wonder from where taken from. Division between integer will give an integer value so there absolutely no need to convert anything to floating points and call any rounding function. ;-)
+1 to Lucas' comment. Performing a division by shifting bits here doesn't while invoking the python interpreter doesn't seem to be a performance vs readability win.

The very first of these objects will define the ccache and put it in the environment.

Maybe we need an assignment here:

else:

which should have been set by the first object to go through this.

And then -- maybe we need to enclose this in a lock to make sure two different caches are set up ..
